title: Mazzer Espresso Grinder Hopper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Replacement Hopper and matching lid for a Mazzer Super Jolly Espresso Grinder. Should also work on Mini and Major. This hopper is smaller than the original hopper and is designed to fit under most kitchen cabinets (the Mazzer Super Jolly is otherwise very large). This is also much smaller than either of the Mini hoppers made by Mazzer. This hopper includes a finger guard that also prevents beans from shooting up and out of the hopper. I still recommend using the lid to prevent jumps, but the guard does help keep most beans and particles from escaping. Even with the overhangs and bridge, I was able to print this on a Flashforge Creator (Replicator 1 clone) without supports. I did get some flaws at the top of the finger guard, but they were minor. Printed with 0% fill at 220C using ABS and .15mm resolution. Used Replicator 1 speed defaults in ReplicatorG as I was afraid the bridge might not print well at high speed. A derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49597
Made in openscad.

title: A Maker's Stolmen Shelve Clone v2

description.text:
UPDATE V2
This time around I took it up a notch and made one to fit from floor to ceiling. To do that I had to create some parts to add a clamping foot to the top of the pole. I also had some breakage in both the shelves and one of the feet. So I did some redesigning to overcome the problems.
The shelve bits I remodeled it so 2 1/2 inch long screws will go from front to back as strength reinforcement. When the front part was all plastic, with a lot of weight it ended up cracking and snapping off. I also increased the infill to 40%. So adding these two things together improved the strength of the shelves.
The second issue was that one of the feet broke. The problem was the carpet. So there is enough spacing to allow the rod to ripped right threw. I don't have this problem with my kitchen shelf but the bottom foot is on a hard flat surface. So to fix this I created a modifier for slic3r that made infill the center of the foot 80% wile the rest can be set at 30 so save on filament. Only the center needs the extra strength. Secondly i cut some wood to create a solid flat surface for the feet to stand on while on the carpet.

ORIGINAL
I bought an Ikea stolmen poles and clamps to custom make a nice shelf in my bathroom. While putting it together I saw how simple the design was. My wife asked for something similar but in a smaller space in the kitchen. So i took up the challenge (and save some cash, stolemen isn't cheap) and created my own. To start off with, I love me wired shelves, I have tons of them used in various ways, you can buy them in pieces if you want to make something custom. For only 7 bucks a pole at homedepot, I was off to a great start (stolmen poles are 30 each). Looking around the bolt isle I discovered "carriage bolts"... they're perfect for the bottom foot which stolen uses a ball to allow the foot to tilt in case the floor is uneven. From there all I need was some wood and design myself the rest of the parts. So here you have it, the finished product looks and works great. I have plans to make another one to hold up my LCD tv in the bedroom plus add much needed storage space, so I'll post up pics when that's done. So I would love to see what you guys do with home made stolmen shelving. Start preheating them printers :)

Just need 6-32 round head screws for the clamps  
For the bottom foot, you just need a carriage bolt, nut and washer. Get whichever bolt can be screwed into the bottom of the wired shelf post.  
Also I used electrical tape on the inside of the clamps, so when you tighten the clamps to the pole they get a nice tight friction grip and won't slide down easily.  
For reference, I printed everything at 25 infill. If you're planning to put a lot of weight on the shelves you might want a higher infill for the clamps. Also if you plan to alot of tension you might have to make the feet higher infill as well. But for me 25 works out just fine.  
Lastly, On the feet I cut circles of this stick on rubbery sheet I found at Micheals. This helps the feet grip itself to the ceiling and floor so they don't slip. If you can't find it you can probably use stuff at home depot, they should have gasket sheets and rubber packing sheets. Those cost more then the micheal's stuff but any rubbery stuff you can cut and glue to the bottom of the feet that causes alot of friction would do the job nicely.

remixed_from.author: koenkooi
remixed_from.title: Another Mendel Inspired Drop-In Makerbot Y-Stage

title: Parametric Mendel Inspired Y-Stage for TOM

description.header: DON'T PRINT THIS - at the moment. The rod-distance is wrong and too short. I need further investigation but don't have time to adjust the files at the moment.
description.text:
I cleared the code and made it parametric. As I have a newer Makerbot TOM on my desk which uses different rod sizes than his design, I needed to adjust the file. I wanted to create a Mendel-Style-Y-Stage that can be adjusted to different bearings and rods.
So this is it. ;) You should be able to use quite every bearing (in a certain range) with quite every rod diameter (in a certain range). The design could be further improved to be more flexible, especially concerning the distance of the rods. This is why I leave the thing as a "work in progress". I did not have the time to test my design on my own printer, so maybe I come up with plenty of "oh no, that won't work" - so print it on your own risk! I don't know if it is working with the endstops, the belt and so on. I'll keep this thing updated when I get more information on this.
But I'm really interessted in your comments and remarks!
See thing:3697 for parts list.
Update 21.07.2011: This thing is supposed to be used for a ToM of the latest design. It has different rod-sizes than the cupcake and maybe from older ToM-versions, too (I don't really know the history of the ToM).

Printing should be easy. If you have 10 623 bearings, a rod distance of 40mm and a rod diameter of 9.5 - just print the two stl's. Follow the instructions of thing 3697 (that is thing 3202).
If you want to adjust the setting, download the zip-file. It contains all you need to render your own stl. See the OpenSCAD-File for further instructions. It is fully commented and you're able to show and hide the different parts. To generate your own stl's set draw_MainPart to 1 for the main-part and draw_Clamp to 1 for the clamp.

comments.text: So are you saying I could use this with 624 bearings? I haven't opened the Openscad file yet. Also what method are you using to attach the HBP? ANy pics of it installed? Videos?  :)
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The 624 bearings are the ones used in the thing i derivated (thing 3697). You just could use that one instead.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: I don't quite understand.
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: The original was designed for a cupcake, this one has been made compatible with the ToM, and potentially any remix of rods and bearings within a sane range.

comments.text: Yes, that's right. Sorry, I missed that point in the description. I'll update it to clear this out.

description.text: V slot end cap 20X40 for OX CNC
Once again parts 4 ox cnc

I bought a laser cutter. The worst part of calibration seems to be aligning the mirrors. The laser beam is invisible and very dangerous, so the recommended way takes days and goes like this:
  • put new paper/tap on the 3 mirrors
  • fire invisible CO2 beam
  • look at holes in paper/tape
  • adjust mirrors
  • remove old paper/tape
  • repeat
    including a lot of opening and closing machine in the middle. If you had a mostly harmless visible beam that matched the C02 beam then you could adjust the mirrors in minutes. ...and that's why I made this.

• Get a $10 cat annoying laser
  • Print two copies of this part. It is printed on it's side to prevent delamination problems.
  • Bolt them together with 25mm M3s so that they clamp onto the cat laser. The middle finger on the holder should push the button on the cat laser. The holder has long fingers so that the laser can be tilted, if necessary.
  • Rest it on a flat surface. You can also use the bottom hole to mount it on an M3 rod (which would need a base of some kind).
  • Put the tape on the mirrors.
  • Fire the C02 once.
  • Move the cat laser stand so that the red dot goes through all the tape holes. Both lasers now match. Do not move cat laser again.
  • Remove tape.
  • Align mirrors.
  • Turn off and remove cat laser.
  • Go mess with your pets.
    This has not yet been tested so I would appreciate your feedback.

comments.text: How do you set a mirror in between the laser tube and the 1st machine´s mirror?  I have a gap of only 3cm. Thanks!!

comments.text: that's not enough of a gap for you?  put a right angle mirror in the gap so you don't have to fit the whole cat laser in the gap.

description.text: I have my Panavise Jr mounted to a heavy duty (hard disk) magnet, which keeps it very stable on my metal work surface.  To catch falling bits and prevent parts and tools from sticking to the underside, I created a parts tray with a skirt.

You can see the magnet under my Panavise Jr, which I coated with Plasti-Dip to prevent scratching the work surface (a large PC case side panel screwed to the desk -- powder coated steel, edges taped with heavy duty pipe freeze tape)  
The tray fits over the top of the panavise and is glued in place.   
The skirt is 33mm high, but the height would probably need to be adjusted to match your vise mounting (print the tray first, attach it, and measure).  Print the skirt and glue it to the bottom of the tray.
The diagonal lines make this box look sleek and modern. It even comes with a lid!
I made it in SketchUp 8.

description.text:
I use these cheap 4" / 100mm magnetic trays for parts and they work really well.  Except small pieces will get stuck to the magnet on the underside.  I designed two versions of a skirt to keep debris away from the magnet.  
The first is a very basic shield which goes up to the tray lip. You have to glue it in place if you want it to stay with the tray when you lift it.  
The second version is shorter, grips the rubber covering of the magnet snugly and stays on by itself.

title: 5x Tablet Stand for 10" or 7" /W integrated cable management

description.text:
Im designing a tablet stand to use for testing multiple tablets at work, this particular design we didn't end up using, since i wanted to integrate a USB hub on later revisions. I spent time on this so i figure i might as well share it.  
The photos are a earlier prototype, the files provided include new center pieces that include cable routing splines that allow you to route cables without unplugging them from the device(s). i also tweaked the walls to have a slight curve so the device will less likley slip out if for example using a 10in tablet in vertical mode.

adjust the pegs if using a different material or size, and cut out i designed it to cut out on 1/4 Poplar Hobby board (0.280"in exact size) from our VersaLaser, Settings used to cut out in one to two passes with minimal burn is:
Power 100%
Speed 8%
DPI 1000%

description.text:

Sometimes the tool comes with a cover.  Mine did not.  
Print in something flexible, like NinjaFlex.  If you print in something rigid, like ABS, you might need to scale the print up a little bit.  
I was able to print without support.  
Note that Adafruit sells the PZ-57 which is meant for smaller screws.  I don't know if this cover will fit those.

description.text:
This contraption holds wires end-to-end while you solder them.  
They use magnets to attach themselves to a metal work surface and apply slight clamping pressure.  
They clamp down on the wire like a clamshell, with the foam applying light pressure.  The lever makes it easy to open the lid.

Print two sets. You shouldn't need support.  Print the "lever" on edge.  
Use 1/8" or 3mm rod for the small connectors -- you might need to drill out the holes for a smooth fit.  
Use 1/4" or 6mm rod for the main hinge. Again, drill the holes if needed.  
Use two screws to "lock" the bases in position on the hinge rod.  
Use 1/16" rod or a finish nail to attach the lever to the lid.  
Glue 4 magnets to each base and 2 to each lid.  The indents are sized for 12mm x 1mm round magnets.   
Glue in a square of low density foam to the inside of the lid.  If the foam is too thick or stiff,  the lid will not snap down and hold.   I used the foam that comes in microchip packaging,  but had to test several types before finding the right thickness and density.

ABS plastic was Inland Black ABS at 210C.

title: DJI Phantom 3 - Battery Charging Hub power retainer clip

description.text: Phantom 3 - Battery Charging Hub Power retainer clip. I bought this great DJI Phantom 3 Professional and I also bought the charging hub. The issue is the clip that connect the hub to the power brick has no mechanism to lock it in place. It slides off really easy, and if you move a wire, it likely can fall off and your stuff wont charge. So i made a keyed bracket that slides under it with a groove to keep it in place. It fits perfectly and prints quickly.

comments.text: Exactly what I needed! Printed perfectly, and works great. Thanks for the print!

author: eLguSo

description.text:
Update: This "Revision One Quadcopter" is no longer supported. I learned some new tricks and better things are to come. This was designed entirely in Tinkercad back in early 2012. Now it's finally being released to the public. It's very easy to build if I do say so myself. http://youtu.be/HHRKwZdfyoc Essential hardware you will need for the frame includes:
  • 24x 35mm M4 socket-cap screws (For mounting center hub to arms and landing gear to arms)
  • 16x 25mm M4 socket-cap screws (For mounting arms to motor mounts)
  • 16x 14mm M3 socket-cap screws (For mounting motor cross-plates to motor mounts.)
    • 4x 6mm M3 socket-cap screws (For mounting flight controller)
  • 4x 20mm M3 nylon standoffs (Also for mounting flight controller)
  • M3 nylon nuts (Also for mounting flight controller)
  • M3 and M4 nylock nuts (To hold everything together)
  • At least 1m of 19mm / 1.5mm square aluminium tubing (Will be measured, cut, and drilled to form the arms)
    • The motor mounts are designed to carry the 28xx series cross plates of your motors. Read instructions.

When printing, print the motor mounts and landing gear (skids) at 100% or so. The top and bottom center hubs should be printed at no less then 18% infill with at least four shells. You'll want these shells to create a kind of buffer when you need to bore out holes or file down certain sections.
  • Cut four 235mm long pieces of 19mm / 1.5mm square aluminum tubing and clean/file the inner and outer edges. You can use "tool-miter_box_90.stl" if you don't have a better way of making perfectly perpendicular cuts.
  • Slide "tool-hole_drill_template.stl" on the end of each bar and use a marker to accurately mark each hole.
  • When drilling, you can use a 5/32inch bit for these 4mm holes. These holes must be as perpendicular as possible, so unless you have a drill press I suggest you mark and drill from each side on each end of the bar.
  • Align the holes and push in a motor mount into one end of each bar. The mount should stop when the tab on the bottom touches the bar. Use some 25mm M4 socket-cap screws and nylock nuts to hold them together.
  • Now test to see how the bars fit into both hubs. Use a file or sand paper to refine these if necessary. They should be a moderately snug fit. Also, drill out the blocked holes on the bottom hub. These made it easy for your printer to print the overhangs.
  • Get some 35mm M4 socket-cap screws and insert them into the recessed holes on the bottom hub. Align them with the empty holes you drilled on the bars. The flat parts of the motor mounts should face upwards when the center bottom hub is at the bottom.
  • Take the top hub and insert any combination of add-on "shelves" (gopro or slotted) into the triangular cut outs from the inside. You very well may need to refine these edges to get them to fit. Don't force them.
  • Take a four 6mm M3 socket-cap screws and insert them into the recessed holes on the underside of the top hub. Secure these from the underside with four 20mm M3 nylon standoffs.
  • Align the holes on the top hub with the screws protruding from the assembly below. The aluminum bars should sit flush with the cavities on the hubs. Secure it all gingerly with a few nylock nuts.
  • Finally, get the two halves of a landing gear assembly and insert some 35mm M4 socket-cap screws into the piece with the recessed holes. Sandwich an aluminum arm between this and an actual landing gear piece. Again, gingerlly tighten these down. Actually, keep them loose so you can adjust them later to eliminate slack in the ESC wires. Each landing gear incorporates a clip to secure any ESC with a 24mm width. I suggest you use Turnigy Plush 18amp or 25amp ESCs.
    • The rest is up to you. But if you want to know more, visit the full write up with images here: http://goo.gl/gGZf7

comments.text: I really like your design. I was wondering if you could tell me what you final weight was?  I realize it depends on a lot of things, but am looking at what is possible to see if mine is in the same ballpark when I print it. Thanks a bunch!
comments.author: Bschulth

comments.text: Mine, minus the battery and GoPro turned out to be 1150g. That is with 100% infill on everything except the center hubs which are 18%. I'm sure you can get away with infills below 50% on the motor mounts and still retain their strength. Also, if weight turns out to be an issue, you can drill large holes in the aluminium tubing and/or shorten the arms with respect to the prop sizes.
comments.author: Bschulth

The first bowl is based on the rhombicosidodecahedron, the second on its dual, and the third on the composite of the two polyhedra.  The rhombicosidodecahedron makes a pleasing bowl - it has triangular, square, and pentagonal faces, all with the same edge length, the triangles share edges with the squares, and the squares share edges with the pentagons.  The dual has 60 identical faces, shaped like kites.  Vertices of the kites are shared by 3, 4 or 5 kites and these meeting points protrude through the corresponding faces of the rhombicosidodecahedron in the composite.  OpenSCAD code is included.
The bowls were printed on a Replicator using 0.3 mm layers without support.  The bowls share a scale and properly oriented it is obvious that the composite bowl is the union of the other two.

title: HICTOP Prusa i3 Y-axis Belt Holder (rework)

description.text:
Modified the HICTOP Prusa i3 Y-Axis belt holder to improve the following characteristics:
  • thicker jaws for holding belt, reducing the chance of belt becoming lose when printing for extended period of time and high temperature bed settings by increasing thickness (increasing tolerance)
  • increased the distance between the two jaws so belt from each side could be folded and be placed side by side inside the grove more easily so the belt lines up properly (the original design is too tight, and the second belt would not fit, therefore causing the belt to have offset from each side and will not be straight)
  • In case of the HICTOP Prusa i3, it seems it can handle curved sides easier for fast printing when printing in ABS. The model may suffer from curling, or the y-axis skips tooth if there are sharp edges and the belt holder is worn out. Curved corners reduces the chance of Y-axis skipping gear dues to sudden acceleration. Makes it easier to print using the retiring Y-axis belt-holder!)
    • Everything, including the y-axis end-stop fits just fine. I have printed using ABS at both 0.1 and 0.2mm resolutions, at 60% fill using ABS. Version 2:
  • modified the belt slot for better fit and increased tolerance (hopefully there is less need for sanding down the tooth to make the belt fit).
  • Added place holder for the nuts. you can use pliers to fit the nuts in the holes before installing the part so hopefully makes installation of the part easier.

comments.text: Would PLA warp due to the heatbed or do you think it would be ok?

comments.text: Well, you can try it. PLA (depending on colour and type)starts getting soft at around 50 degrees or so (slightly hot to touch water). It might work if your bed is not going to be hotter than that (theoretically).

Thanks to adafruit for the idea and stevemedwin to inspire me to make it customizable.

title: Generic mount for Webcam or other accessories

description.text: Just a simple 3 piece arm and mount for any webcam or any other small accessories (for example an LED light) that you might want to attach to 8mm threaded rod. Just change the "camera mount" to anything that fits 10mm diameter hole on the "Rod"). I printed the nut and bolt that would fit the 8mm threaded rod, (available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647) so I did not use any other hardware. They work much better than I expected. I am currently using it to hold a Logitech c910/c920 webcam without having to take apart it's factory stand (I could not find one that doesn't require the webcam original parts to be disassembled on Thingiverse). The Design-Spark file is also attached so you can customize anything as you see fit for your purpose.

description.text:
Jameco: T100T1B1A1QN
http://www.jameco.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/Product_10001_10001_76523_-1 *This is NOT a functional part. It is intended for modeling enclosures only.

Very simple: You need, a stepper motor.
a 3d printer
those 2 printed parts.
an android cell phone (or tablet)
a line laser, like: http://www.ebay.ca/itm/650nm-5mW-Red-Laser-Line-Module-Focus-Adjustable-Laser-Head-5V-good-/381374426229?hash=item58cbafec75 Download and install this app: scan3doid (around 5$) https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.gsohler.scan3droid&hl=fr_CA Then I suggest unplugging x motor from your 3d printer and plug your new scanner's one. Or, you can also prepare a parallel plug so that when you install the scanner, both the x motor and the scanner motor will move at the same time. Now you have to determine how many "x mm" makes a complete revolution of the stepper. To do it, I used pronterface and counted the number of mm +1 before one complete revolution. for me it was 40mm. Then send G92 X0, This sets, x to zero, without the need of hitting the end stop. Then send a command G1 X40 F20 the x is the number you just determined earlier. and the f is the speed... If it goes too fast or too slow, play with it. The best is when it makes a complete revolution in 50-55 sec. Install the camera lens just where the arrow points: it makes a nice 30 deg between laser and camera. I suggest using a heat gun to shape the cellphone support to your cell phone. When you are ready, use the app to record video and follow the instructions of the app. The app is not perfect, but it works. I then had to make little "cleaning, but you can see the shape of the toy I scanned. I've put an original stl file direct from the app.

title: LED Light for cardboard box (3D Printer Heat shroud) with momentary push button

description.text:
We put a cardboard box over our 3d printer to help with temperature regulation / ABS warp. I cut a viewing window and covered with packing tape, all that was needed was a light.  
This obviously can be adapted for any situation that calls for a cardboard box light.  
Thanks semih86 for the battery box design.

The LED (hobbyking sourced) is stuck to the bottom of the "Z" end bit, and the assembly can be "mounted" to the box with only 2 small cuts in the cardboard, to minimise heat loss.  
some small screws were used for the switch contacts. Wires were soldered on to washers, and battery terminals fashioned from washers and scrap springs.  
I had better luck printing this sideways, as removing support material from the flexible "switch" lever part proved troublesome. Your milage may vary. The top surface definely looks better when printed flat (stl as-is).

title: Lulzbot Taz 4, 5 or 6 Removable Build Bed Upgrade

description.text:
This is a removable build bed design that you can make as an upgrade for your Taz 4, Taz 5 or Taz 6. It is comprised of a precision machined, level adjustable, ultra lightweight aluminum tray with magnets and separate square glass bed with ABS handles, also with embedded magnets. The glass bed can be simply pulled off the aluminum tray while still hot, immediately post print. No tools are required for removal or leveling. The bed is held firmly in place by the powerful magnets and friction between the silicone heater pad and the glass. Leveling is achieved via three always easily accessible thumb nuts located underneath the stock Y axis tray. This design has been fully tested for several months by me, and I can happily attest that it works flawlessly. I use hairspray and an enclosure (See my enclosure design here:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:746922) , which works perfectly and allows the use of any printing material available provided you have the correct extruder. Some materials may require other surfaces however, and there is no reason why you couldn't cover the glass with PEI, PrintinZ (Or anything else), especially if you prefer not to use an enclosure or hairspray. This is a huge advantage over stock because you can remove your printouts from the printer while they are still attached to the bed, so you remove them and start printing again quickly. And removing the part (along with the bed), will not throw the printer out of level because you do it away from the machine. Sometimes, on the stock Taz, I had to work so hard to remove a print, the printer would no longer be level ! But with this upgrade, the leveling tray itself never leaves the printer. You can remove the part from the bed in an open and unrestricted area, free to pry (if you're using PEI) as hard as you like without upsetting level. You can also use multiple glass beds and swap them out as you want, dramatically decreasing the time between prints, so you can get more parts out of your printer per day. The only permanent (this upgrade can easily be undone, but you won't want to) mod to the stock printer is to drill 5/32" (4mm) holes (4x) in the existing aluminum Y travel plate for mounting of the aluminum leveling tray. Leveling is achieved via three knurled thumb nuts at three corners located under the stock Y travel tray. The fourth corner is fixed in height via the printed spacer. The glass is borosilicate and can be 1/8" 3/16" or 1/4" thick. Thicker is sturdier, but takes longer to heat. Beware 1/4" thick takes about 30 minutes to heat up, so I don't recommend it. The 1/8th inch thick glass heats to printing temperature very fast, just a couple minutes or so. 3/16th thick is much stronger, but takes about ~10 minutes to get to 105 C. The Z knob adjustment screw needs to be modded taller since this tray sits slightly higher than stock. But this is achieved with a simple 3D printed part that is pressed onto the existing Z knob. User installation can be done in less than an hour (assembly of the components will take longer, as the adhesives need to cure overnight). Changes to the heated bed PID values via pronterface is recommended but not required. Otherwise the printer operates as stock. Advantages:
The entire bed is clear of obstruction so the entire print surface can be used regardless of type of extruder or even a dual extruder. Nothing protrudes above the glass bed surface, anywhere. The stock bed had large protrusions at each corner, which can collide with the print head, especially the dual extruder, if you aren't careful. No more collision worries! PEI can be omitted (with the use of enclosure) so no more hopelessly stuck parts. Use hairspray for trouble free adhesion.
But any type of surface can easily be added to the glass. Multiple glass beds (perhaps with different surfaces) can be kept on hand and swapped in seconds. The only adjustment would be the Z knob. Actual level would never change with change of glass bed since the leveling portion never leaves the printer. The bed is held in place by powerful magnets pulling down creating friction with the silicon heater pad which is in direct contact with the glass. So, the bed won't move unless you want it to, because the friction between the silicone rubber and the glass is very high. Easy to remove glass beds can be lifted out immediately post print without tools for quick cooling and MUCH easier part removal, all without altering bed level in the printer. Leveling the bed is much easier than stock as well. It can be done in just a few minutes. The stock version took forever to level and required a hex drive to do it. And access to the screws was sometimes obscured making leveling often an exercise in frustration. But, with this upgrade, no tools are necessary, just adjust the three thumb nuts which are always easy to access, to quickly get your bed system ready to print on. Update 09-21-2015 Upgrade instructions now available for download!
Update 10-14-2015 Added file Lulzbedspacer.stl.
Update 10-21-2015 Revised Parts list and Instruction manual
Update: 12-8-2015 Aluminum leveling tray component of this upgrade now available on Amazon. Note this is just one component of the upgrade. See the parts list for all required components.
http://www.amazon.com/Printer-Aluminum-Carriage-Upgrade-Replaceable/dp/B0192K4N6K/ref=sr_1_4?ie=UTF8&qid=1449543059&sr=8-4&keywords=3D+printer+bed+Taz
Update 04-21-2016 Revised Parts List and Instruction Manual
Update 07-09-2016 Added trilevelbar-reve.stl to provide 3 point leveling feature. This part mounts to the bottom of the aluminum leveling tray with flat head 6-32 x 3/8" long screws (2, replacing existing 6-32x1.25 screws at two corners), with a 6-32 x 1.25" long screw at the center pointing towards the Y axis tray. Apply spring from parts list and 6-32 thumbscrew under stock Y axis tray to create a 3 point leveling system. Coming soon: Carbon fiber Y axis tray replacement for incredible rigidity greatly simplifying leveling and making 3 point leveling even more effective. See new pictures for more details.
Update 12-14-2016 Use with the Taz 6 would require end user to provide mounting for wipe pad. Also if autolevel feature is desired, mounting of conductive pads at corners of bed. The removable bed's mechanical leveling is so simple and stable, the need for auto leveling is questionable at best.
Update 06-28-2017 Carbon fiber Y axis replacement tray available on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Carbon-Fiber-Axis-Removeable-Printer/dp/B071LTS8W8/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1498681091&sr=8-2&keywords=carbon+fiber+Y+axis.
This is a super light super rigid Y axis tray to replace the flimsy aluminum one on the stock Taz printer. Makes leveling super easy with the removable bed system because adjustments to the springs will not flex the Y axis tray which will make leveling more intuitive. Price is $169.25 shipped in USA. This has the same hole pattern as the stock tray at the bearing connections, but has 3 holes for mounting the removable bed system (with the three point leveling print installed on the leveling tray. Do not use the 4 corner mount method with the CF tray you could damage your printer with too low a z setting in the corner with the standoff as there is no flex in the CF tray. The three point method has springs supporting the entire bed providing the necessary safety cushion in case you set Z too low). See last 6 photos on this page to see carbon fiber tray, 3 point leveling and how it looks mounted.

Update 09-13-2017 Silicone heater required for this upgrade is now available here: http://www.ebay.com/itm/152256021623 Please note this heater will require 5mm of trimming on the fore and aft edges to fit the handles of the glass. But this is not a problem with this heater. Or you can buy a 290mm square heater direct from China via google search. Sorry the original source of this heater is having problems as a going concern. See upgrade instructions pdf file for full instructions! See parts list pdf file for order information for all components. Update 10/21/2015 Small errors corrected in parts list and instruction manual. Please download again if you downloaded them at a prior date for the most up to date info. Update 12/9/2015 Parts list updated
Update 1/7/2016 Removed docx files, replaced with pdf files (for instructions and parts list)
Update 3/24/2017 Added file Levelbedtest.stl for help in doing final dialing in of bed level. Print this file after leveling bed as best you can via measurement and then while it is printing adjust three leveling knobs until all lines are about equal thickness.This will get your glass as level as possible given surface tolerances and sag of your printer.

The Carbon fiber tray is extremely light and rigid making adjustment to the bed level easier since the stock Y tray made of aluminum is very flimsy and reacts to adjustments unnecessarily complicating the leveling procedure.
comments.author: billyd

comments.text: I am working on putting together all the parts for this. I talked to a 3M rep about the 2216 and the primer you mentioned, since it's so hard to acquire and requires HAZMAT certification to ship the primer. He recommended 3M 94 Yellow Tape Primer paired with 3M DP-110 adhesive. Have you tried this combination? I think I'm going to go with this just to see how it works out, unless you've already tried it and found it to be unsuitable. If it doesn't, I'll go with your recommendation, but the 94 Primer and DP-110 are much easier to source and are a lot cheaper.
comments.author: joshz

comments.text: The links in the parts list should help you locate everything. The primer can be purchased on Ebay in individual bottles (or used to be available there). The 2 part adhesive is on Amazon, along with the dispenser.

comments.text: One thing about the silicone is you can reuse the magnets in new bed handles if you damage your bed glass and want to make a new bed. If you use the 2216 epoxy those magnets will not be reusable.
comments.author: billyd

comments.text: I have found a much better source for super flat borosilicate glass. Grayglass.net has 4mm borosilicate glass that is much flatter than the McMaster-Carr stuff. About .001 to .003 surface tolerance, whereas the McMaster-Carr glass is up to .008". Unfortunately you have to order 3 12" squares as a minimum order and it's freight shipping so it's $185 total in the USA for 3 glass beds. That actually is only about $10 more per sheet than McMaster, but you have to buy 3. But this glass is far superior.
comments.author: billyd

comments.text: So long story short the PrintinZ build plate can be used by adhering it to the glass bed assembled according to the installation instructions of this upgrade. You will need an appropriate adhesive that can handle the materials and the heat.
comments.author: Pixeldesire

comments.text: It will work with any printing surface that can either be adhered (or clamped*) to the recommended glass. Or it can act as a standalone bed (replace the glass) if it is 12"x12" (305mm square) by at least 1/8" (3mm) thick, and is both rigid and flat. Remember the plate on Amazon is just one component of this upgrade. See the parts list and upgrade instruction documents in the files section of this upgrade.
comments.author: Pixeldesire

comments.text: Thank you! I really enjoy my Taz printer with this bed. Much less frustrating to use.
comments.author: Phoolster

comments.text: I dont understand why people are still having trouble with prints sticking too hard or not sticking. I have a taz 4, and I bought a 1/8" thick 12"x24" sheet of PEI from amazon and some 6" 3m tape, cut the sheet in half and stuck it to the top of bed. I have a e3d v6 nozzle and I use elmers purple glue stick with every filament and my prints stick perfect and pop off the bed with the clam nife that came with it. I use 3 layers of glue stick and heat the bed to recommended temps. Also because it is 1/8" thick PEI it never bubbles or rips. Also I print perfect prints with taulman bridge, alloy 910, tglase, tritan etc. I havnt had to re-level the bed in 4 months. If you are still having trouble shoot me an email at [email protected] I Wish everyone could experience trouble free printing like me, it leaves you much more time to print!
comments.author: sunnugget

comments.text: This removable bed system can employ any surface you want over the glass. Just like the stock Taz bed is glass with a PEI layer. This upgrade has several other huge advantages over the stock Taz bed and they are clearly listed on this thing's thinginfo page.

This is another version of Round Clock
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001638 Here, I am using "eto" substitute for ordinally numbers. The eto (十二支) is a index system developed in old china (over 4000 years ago), and it divides time, direction and even human life into 60 parts (period). Also every indexes are not simple numbers but "animals". This is really interesting. The first one (0, not 1 or 12 in china) is "Mouse". 3rd is "Rabbit". 6th one is "Cow". 9th one is "Bird". And all animals are written in one simple Kanji each. Is not it smart?

There is no good "Gold" ABS, so I painted them. 2nd from right was used.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xL9a-CLuOdU

If you want to make a Round Clock with "your own symbols", please draw them as eps (or .ai), and send them to me. I will convert and fit them to the Round Clock. Or if you can use CINEMA 4D, make it by your hands.
http://www.11moon.com/minne/Round_Clock/round_clock_116.zip
http://www.11moon.com/minne/Round_Clock/round_clock_116_eto.zip

Sept. 25, 2015
Some parts were updated (arrow, arrow2).

I am using DaVinci 1.0 3D printer by XYZ printing. Layer pitch is 0.3mm.
Normal speed and normal shell thickness. No raft. No support.
With stick paste(Tombow, Shiwanashi PIT). 480 minutes to print. 60 minutes for shaping, constructing and sanding.
40m for ABS. Use jig to place numbers to correct position Other parts,
1 clock movement module (typically 3-4$)
1 AA battery Also if you have ø3.7 and ø5.5 hand reamers, they should help you to make hole on arrows accurately.

Only text parts were changed from original Round Clock, so other parts (face, body, arrows) are common with it. However these parts were slightly changed by some reasons.

  • gap between text and arrows.

  • readability.

  • to hide center nut.

description.text:
Jameco: 3386P-1-103/63P103
http://www.jameco.com/webapp/wcs/stores/servlet/Product_10001_10001_43001_-1 *This is NOT a functional part. It is intended for modeling enclosures only.

Dust Plug for the lightning connector found on iPhones and iPads.
Modeled based on iPhone 5 *UPDATE
due to the long term effects of using REV 1 design, I've updated the design to only sit in the first portion of the socket, instead of protruding all the way past the pins.
I've also included the solidworks part files so you can tweak the overall shape to suit your printer/phone.

Notes: due to its small size and the small tolerances, you'll have to tweak the plugs thickness to suit your printer and or your phone. I also recommend printing with a skirt or raft due to its small size.

Will require some light sanding to remove skirt (if used), and retraction marks.
It may also require some filling to reduce the thickness of the plug to fit into the phone.

General The design was based on my own iPhone 5 and its USB cable. REV 1 REV 1, was design to lock into the lightning port internal clips (thus the cut outs in the top portion), the same clips that hold the USB cable in. But after long term use I found that the plug flattened the pins in the iPhone. REV 2 REV 2, was designed o sit in the first portion of the socket with a small interference fit to hold it in.

comments.text:
After using this on my phone over the last 6 months, I suspect it has flattened the pins in the socket.
I'll start working on the next rev. as soon as I can.

title: Calibration for resin printers, 5mm tall for quick test HD High Def
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This test / calibration model is designed to be printed very quickly and without complications (no supports):
just press print for "Hello World". The STL is in high definition so that the precision of the print is limited by the printer, not by the model. For reference, on a B9Creator, this STL completes in about 10 minutes at 50 micron z (100 layers)...
... or in about 15 minutes at 75 micron z. There are several rounded items. Unit is millimeter. All objects are 5 tall:
  • a cylinder of diameter 10 and 1 wall thickness (so radius 4+1)
  • two arches, each is 2 thick
  • hemisphere of diameter 10
  • half cube, 10 side, rounded at 3
  • six cylinders with diameters of 1, 1.5, 2 ...up to 3.5

The settings of the photos are:
B9C version 1.1 and Spot-A-HT version 7.
50 microns x, 50 y, 50.8 z.
4 base layers of which the first two cured at 10 seconds, then 3+2 seconds.
First photo: "just out".
Second photo "cleaned" from uncured resin and "cured" 2 minutes under UV light. When curing in UV light, turn the object to prevent warping.

comments.text: Nice print! Do you mix the b9 resin and spota resin? As I tested the spota resin has high shink rate, the outcome is just like the model in the third pic.
comments.author: MakeX

comments.text: Thanks MakeX!  Your comment is very interesting. I have been using pure Spot-A-HD, so far. It is a great resin for precision details, but I do have issues with shrinking in some models. It is very interesting to read your suggestion to mix Spot-A-HD with Red / Cherry as a possible improvement to shrinking. As I am based in Europe, I tend to use as little as possible of USA resins, because of shipping costs reasons.

remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi 3, Pi 2, and Model B+ case with VESA mounts and more

title: Raspberry Pi 2 (or B+) case with DB9/DE9/DE15 RS232/VGA hole

description.text:
This is a remix of  'Raspberry Pi 2 (or B+) case with VESA mount case' of  0110-M-P. Please use his bottom (well, of his case at least) and this top.  
The hole fits any DB9 (=DE9, this is mostly used for RS232 ports) and DE15 (used for VGA ports).   
I use a Raspberry Pi 2 in this case to interface with an old Texas Instruments 924 CRT terminal.

I imported his STL file into Sketchup and added the DB9 hole, then exported again to STL.
  • When printing, use supports.
  • Desolder and remove the display connector from the Raspberry Pi 2 by
  • Unscrew the bolts of the DB9/DE9/DE15 connector, put it through the hole and screw the back in. Use washers when needed.
  • Or instead of #3 find a way to attach the RS232 PCB to the Raspberry'S PCB or to the case.
    • The RS232 I use is this one: http://www.davidhunt.ie/add-a-9-pin-serial-port-to-your-raspberry-pi-in-10-minutes/ (you'll need a 5V capable RS232 to interface with older devices, one with a MAX3232 chip is recommended)

My friend and I were putting together a Prusa from Clonedel parts and had a lot of reliability problems with the couplings that link the z motors and threaded rod leadscrews.  We tried printing some of the couplings already uploaded, but the printer was not yet working well enough to make them.  These couplings have a very simple geometry that enabled them to be printed on our humble machine.  Probably not too efficient material-wise, but they definitely do the job.

Print them and bolt them on.  Use nylocks or double-nuts, only failure occurred when I first tried single nuts.  The attached trig diagram on the left should make the OpenSCAD parameters more understandable.  The .stl is for a 5mm motor shaft and 5/16" threaded rod leadscrew.

A bit similar to the "thumbwheel nut" I previously posted but this one was designed as a replacement for some broken parts on a cheap light stand (http://dx.com/p/603-magnalium-folding-studio-photography-light-tripod-black-max-5kg-164000). Many parameters can be adjusted in the SCAD file in order to customize the part to different needs.

Just print if you have a 8mm nut.   
Customize and print if you need a different diameter. There are a set of variables in the SCAD file to change the dimensions.  
After a few tests we settled for 0.22mm layers, 3 shells and 35% infill. Printer in PLA on a Replicator 2.  
The weak part is the hexagon holding the nut. If you need to tighten the nut hard, it is probably a good idea to properly glue it in place.

comments.text: If you need more strength, print the O.D. at the hex for a snug fit in a piece of metal conduit or other thin wall pipe. Press the pipe section on first, then press in the nut. This should allow you to torque it down a bit more without breakage.

description.text:
This platform holds a piece of tissue during a frozen section procedure.  
During surgery a small portion of tissue is frozen and thinly sectioned (about 5-7 microns), then the section is stained for a Pahtologist to look at (while the patient is still on the operating table).  The immediate evaluation can change the course of the operative procedure depending on what is seen in the tissue.  
This platform is also something that I for my research and there never seem to be enough clean FS holders  to go around, so I made my own.  
Using this base you can design any shape or length if for example you wanted to cut oversized frozen sections or long thin ones etc...  
On one platform I covered one surface with a metallic paint but there doesn't seem to be a difference in how it performs.  
Designed in trueSpace and printed on an Up!3D in Octave ABS, Fine print with 2 layer raft.
Download and print out as many as you need.

author: Cookienator

description.text:
I always prefer blowers vs fans. They are more reliable, silent and put more air. In this case, where you want to blow a tiny area focused on the nozzle, a little air pressure is needed. When I use fans to this same thing a lot more turbulence are created in the air conduct that creates a great resistance for the air to flow, thus the air flow at the nozzle is poor. With a blower things change a lot, a high air pressure zone is created at the end and air doesnt tend to leave the blower at the wrong side (like with a fan happens). So I designed a blower support to be used as layer fan. I designed it robust, modular and simple, to be printed easily, and maybe to be used in other parts of the printer. Also included a support to be screwed to the extruder to attach the blower(s) coming from other of my designs for the L3K. This is a very precise solution, the air blowing is concentrated just into the low level of the nozzle. Do your proof, because the blowing at 100% blower power could be intense for some prints. Printing... No special instructions needed, just use ABS or any high glass transition temperature material. I've got awesome results, better than ever with PLA at 50% power with a standard 50mm blower. Anyway, if you need more, you can even add a optional second blower!!! I can guarantee that the air flow this thingy reaches is way BEYOND the flow achieved with any fan solution I have tried. Last thing: use antirotation washers if you think you need them (although I didn't need them). See also: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:993577
TODO: Nothing. Original goal surpassed. Be careful, dont put it at 100% speed or it will blow away your things from your printer bed :-)
Enjoy!! UPDATES:
(22-SEP-2015) Added a mirrored anchor to mount a second blower on the right (as requested). Increased lenght of the anchor to the same length as the other things (aesthetical reasons). Updated files according, added a new pic of the dual solution. (21-SEP-2015) Blower support: added trim for air entry. Anchor: adjusted offset. Warning, build pic is for old version. Will upload new ones when available. Air redirector: Added a wider, smoother, stronger V2 this should improve even more the cooling. Sources: FreeCad sources & pics added. (18-SEP-2015) Enhanced blower support, redesigned from zero. Pic added.
